title: Why are there damage amplification masteries in the cunning tree in the first place?
body: Correct me if I'm wrong, but isn't the cunning tree supposed to emphasize utility...?

replies.body:
> [{quoted}](name=bikboistyle,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=HjOEUiej,comment-id=,timestamp=2016-01-01T07:08:56.629+0000)
>
> Correct me if I'm wrong, but isn't the cunning tree supposed to emphasize utility...?

You're wrong.

Cunning covers utility, mobility, and burst damage.

There is no utility tree anymore.

each of the 3 is geared to spefific types of champions

ferocity is mages marksman Madcs

cunning is assassins ad casters burst mages supports

resolve is tanks supports bruisers
Cunning has the utility AND the assassin masteries... for some reason...

Not really. It's the utility/burst damage tree. Back when we had a purely utility tree, almost no one went deep into it because almost no one wants that.

Also, by separating burst and sustained damage trees, it's easier to make options for one that don't also greatly benefit or break the other.

I guess, but I still think it's a bummer that there needs to be some damage in the cunning tree for people to even consider spending points there. I was thinking of potential ideas for better cunning keystones along the lines of "spells that grant movement speed leave a trail of iron that hastens other allied units" or something like that to preserve items that have come and gone, but I'm just a plat scrub so...lol

there doesn't "need" to be damage in the cunning tree, Riot put damage into the cunning tree specifically to entice assassins to take it over ferocity. there's a reason they reworked masteries and it wasn't to get the same exact set ups people have been running for the past 5 seasons.

No, it's not.
Cunning tree is to emphasize precision and single target, along with minor utility.  ferocity is for champions looking to dump as much damage as they can onto as many people as they can at once.
